bios.event: The first computer program written (on paper, for a mechanical computer that was never built).
bios.name: Ada Lovelace
bios.blurb: One of the first visionaries of what we know today as computer science, Ada designed the first algorithm intended for a computer, for Charles Babbage's early mechanical general-purpose computer, the Analytical Engine. With her "poetical scientific" sensibilities, Ada envisioned capabilities of machines beyond simple number-crunching.

resources.title: Untangling the Tale of Ada Lovelace
Ada Lovelace, the First Tech Visionary

bios.event: The universal Turing machine lays conceptual foundation for the modern computer.
bios.name: Alan Turing
bios.blurb: Considered the father of theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence, Alan formalised the concepts of algorithm and computation with the Turing Machine. During WWII, Alan's work in cryptanalysis was instrumental in breaking German ciphers. He was also an openly gay man who was prosecuted for "homosexual acts" by the UK and chemically castrated.

bios.event: Yao's Principle published; becomes fundamental to randomised algorithms and complexity.
bios.name: Andrew Chi-Chih Yao
bios.blurb: Andrew's work as computational theorist, including "Yao's Principle," has significantly contributed to the theory of pseudo-random number generation and cryptography.

bios.event: Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing conference established.
bios.name: Anita Borg
bios.blurb: Anita spent her career developing in areas of operating systems, memory systems, email communications, and more, while fiercely advocating for women in technology as the founder of the email network, Systers, and the (Anita Borg) Institute for Women and Technology, and as the co-founder of the Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing conference.

resources.title: Dr. Anita Borg: Technology is changing the world (video)

bios.event: The "Liskov substitution principle" introduced and leaves indelible mark on object-oriented programming.
bios.name: Barbara Liskov
bios.blurb: Barbara's work in programming language design and methodology, including the "Liskov substitution principle," contributed to development in data abstraction, fault tolerance, and distributed computing.

bios.event: IBM Home Page Reader debuts, opening up the web for visually impaired people.
bios.name: Chieko Asakawa
bios.blurb: A blind computer scientist at IBM, Chieko's work is composed of leading research and development in accessibility, including a key role in the development of a word processor for Braille documents, a digital library for Braille documents, and a web-to-speech system, IBM Home Page Reader.

resources.title: Chieko Asakawa: How new technology helps blind people explore the world (video)

bios.event: The internet arrives at the basic structure that we have today.
bios.name: Elizabeth "Jake" Feinler
bios.blurb: Pioneer and manager of various networks that became the basis for the internet, Elizabeth was a part of the teams that developed the Domain Name System (DNS) as well as a program called PCSam that became the basis of today's email systems.

resources.title: Before Google and GoDaddy, There Was Elizabeth Feinler

bios.event: ENIAC (Electronic Numerical Integrator And Computer), the first electronic general-purpose computer, announced.
bios.name: The ENIAC Programmers
bios.blurb: The primary programmers of the ENIAC were six women drafted from a pool of mathematicians known as "computers." The ENIAC programmers not only built software but also knew their hardware, crawling inside the machinery to diagnose and debug problems. Their achievements remained largely invisible to the public, and most of the ENIAC programmers were not invited to the ENIACâ€™s 50th anniversary event.

resources.title: Jean Bartik and the ENIAC Women (video)

bios.event: IBM delivers supercomputer Stretch-Harvest to the NSA.
bios.name: Frances E. Allen
bios.blurb: A pioneer in the field of optimising compilers, Frances introduced many of the abstractions, algorithms, and implementations used for automatic program optimisation technology. Her work was implemented in the compilers for the top secret NSA supercomputer, the Stretch-Harvest.

resources.title: Scientist at Work: Frances Allen; Would-Be Math Teacher Ended Up Educating a Computer Revolution

bios.name: Rear Admiral Grace Hopper
bios.blurb: "Amazing Grace" invented the compiler, which translates human readable programming language into machine executable language. Also a pioneering programmer of the revolutionary Harvard Mark I computer in 1944, she's known as the /
and the first person to use the term "debugging."

bios.event: Frequency-hopping radio system patented; becomes a critical element for today's wifi and Bluetooth technologies.
bios.name: Hedy Lamarr
bios.blurb: An inventor and actress, Hedy co-invented the spread spectrum and frequency hopping communication technologies. It was invented with the purpose of creating jam-proof torpedoes in WWII but was ignored until its applications for the Navy during 1962's Cuban missile crisis, and now is foundational to wifi and Bluetooth technologies. Hedy's long overdue recognition did not come until near the end of her life in 1997.

bios.event: Lead-free technology and manufacturing literature published.
bios.name: Jennie S. Hwang
bios.blurb: A pioneer in environmentally-friendly electronics manufacturing and electronics miniaturisation technology and a renowned entrepreneur, Jennie was also the first Asian-American woman to be elected into National Academy of Engineering.

bios.event: "Nash equilibrium" published; a Nobel winning game theory thesis with computer science applications in networks, scheduling, and more.
bios.name: John Forbes Nash, Jr.
bios.blurb: John's contributions in mathematics, notably game theory, are influential in many fields including computer science and artificial intelligence. He was diagnosed and lived with paranoid schizophrenia, and his story became basis for the biography and film, "A Beautiful Mind."

bios.event: Alan Shepard is the first American in space with his flight trajectory calculated by Katherine Johnson (and not by a machine).
bios.name: Katherine Johnson
bios.blurb: Renowned for her accuracy in celestial navigation (space flight trajectories), Katherine started at NASA as a "computer" in the segregated all black West Area Computers section. She soon transitioned to work as an aerospace technologist, notably, making calculations for the Apollo space programs.

bios.event: First computerised Monte Carlo simulations run on the ENIAC, considered one of the first programs stored in and run from computer memory.
bios.name: Klara Dan von Neumann
bios.blurb: A programmer and key inventor on the ENIAC and a major contributor to the first computerised Monte Carlo simulations, Klara's work is often downplayed in comparison to her husband's. Klara, with Adele Goldstine and Mary Mauchly, was a part of a pioneering group of women who held senior positions working with the ENIAC. In an environment where women primarily existed as extensions of their husbands, these three women arguably received a boost in seniority due to their husbands' ownership of the ENIAC project. This led to tension with the other female ENIAC programmers/operators.

bios.event: "Mead & Conway revolution" triggers breakthrough in chip design education with the textbook, "Introduction to VLSI System Design."
bios.name: Lynn Conway
bios.blurb: Lynn's contributions include pioneering work in chip design, and architecture design that laid the groundwork for modern high performance microprocessors. In 1968, IBM, likely the president of IBM himself, fired Lynn when the company learned that she was transgender. She was denied access to her children after medically transitioning. In 2000, she went public with her story as a trans woman, and began her work in activism.

bios.event: Discovery of the "essence" of an algorithm's complexity (i.e. cost to run), independent of specific machine model, fundamentally changes the study of computational complexity theory. Think Big O numbers!
bios.name: Manuel Blum
bios.blurb: Manuel's machine-independent theory of complexity forms the foundation of computational complexity theory. He is also recognised for his work on the application of complexity theory to cryptography and program checking.

bios.event: Apollo 11 lands first humans on the Moon and returns them to Earth safely.
bios.name: Margaret Hamilton
bios.blurb: As lead Apollo flight software designer at NASA, Margaret and her team built the software allowing Apollo 11 to successfully navigate to and land on the Moon. The robustness of the software prevented a mission abort. She co-developed concepts of asynchronous software, priority scheduling, and more, which became foundational to robust software designs.

bios.event: IBM Personal Computer released; becomes simply known as the "PC," an industry standard of personal computers.
bios.name: Mark Dean
bios.blurb: In the early 1980s, Mark led a 12-person team to design the original IBM PC. He holds three of IBM's original nine PC patents, and is the first black person to become an IBM Fellow. In 1999, Mark led a team that created the first a one-gigahertz computer processor chip.

bios.name: Peter Landin
bios.blurb: Inventor of the first software emulator, Peter freed computer programs from manufacturers and laid the foundations for programming language design based on mathematical logic. Peter was politically radical, bisexual, and highly active in the Gay Liberation Front.

bios.name: Radia Perlman
bios.blurb: Often called "Mother of the internet,"Radia made large contributions to network engineering, and is best known for her invention of the spanning-tree protocol, a technology fundamental to network bridging (connecting multiple networks).

bios.name: Raj Reddy
bios.blurb: One of the early researchers of artificial intelligence, Raj pioneered the study of spoken language systems, such as voice-controlled robots, speech recognition, and dictation.

bios.name: Shafi Goldwasser
bios.blurb: Researcher of cryptography, computational complexity theory, and computational number theory, Shafi co-invented the zero-knowledge protocol, a key cryptographic tool.

bios.name: Sophie Wilson
bios.blurb: Known for designing the Acorn Micro-Computer, Sophie also designed the instruction set of the ARM processor that now drives billions of mobile devices. She is also an out transgender woman.

bios.name: West Area Computers
bios.blurb: "West Area Computers" was a unit of all black female aeronautical research mathematicians at NASA. The unit was originally supervised by white supervisors, segregated under Jim Crow, and denied dormitory housing. Dorothy Vaughan, a black female mathematician, eventually took over as supervisor.

bios.name: Yukako Uchinaga
bios.blurb: At IBM, Yukako led the team that developed software to work with Asian languages such as Chinese, Japanese, and Korean, that require "double byte character sets." She has also been deeply involved in advocacy for women at IBM Japan and Asia Pacific, as well as the Japanese government.

bios.name: Zero
bios.blurb: The first known use of the number zero was in Egypt, where the hieroglyph also meant "beautiful." Without the concept of zero, there would be no computer science as we know it.
